Abstract: Epigenetic regulation plays a crucial role in the life cycle of Plasmodium parasites, the causative agents of malaria. This study investigates the epigenetic mechanisms underlying chromatin remodeling in P. falciparum, the most virulent species of the parasite. We found that long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) are differentially expressed in response to environmental cues, influencing chromatin architecture and gene expression. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed a complex epigenetic landscape, with distinct epigenetic marks associated with different stages of the parasite's life cycle. Our results suggest that epigenetic regulation of chromatin remodeling is essential for P. falciparum survival and virulence, highlighting potential targets for the development of novel antimalarial therapies. Understanding the epigenetic mechanisms underlying P. falciparum biology may provide new insights into the prevention and treatment of malaria.
